articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: His work on complex systems and responsive technologies helped lay the groundwork for later work on artificial intelligence. He is a professor of computer science at the University of California, Santa Barbara. He has written several books on computer science and artificial intelligence, including "The Artificially Intelligent Computer".

articles.title: There are no entry-level jobs anymore. What now?
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: In the age of artificial intelligence and automation, many of the entry-level roles are disappearing. Nearly 80 percent of hiring managers predict that AI could force companies to cut the number of entry level positions in the future due to automation and AI-driven job losses.

articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: AI often ignores instructions even when repeated. Learn why it happens and what you can do to get more consistent results from AI. It's based on memory and prompts play a role, and you can change them to get better results.

articles.title: Bender says AI is a con job. No, this is not an episode of Futurama
articles.summary: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has developed an artificial intelligence called Obvious. It's a machine that translates human brain information into machine language. It works on both human and machine intelligence. It is capable of learning and understanding human behaviour. It can also learn from human intelligence.

articles.title: New Report Highlights AI and the Impact on the Legal Industry
articles.author: Staff Report From Georgia CEO
articles.summary: Bloomberg Law has released its latest report on Artificial Intelligence: The Impact on the Legal Industry. The report is a survey-based overview of how artificial intelligence (AI) is disrupting and reshaping the legal industry. It includes articles by Bloomberg Law's legal analysts that explore the implications of generative AI, state-level regulations and AI's influence on law firm operations.
